_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PROCESS SUMMARY
The Reddy Ice-Dallas (311) facility manufactures packaged ice for wholesale/retail distribution.  The facility has a production capacity of approximately 850 tons of ice per day and utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant for ice production and storage.  The facility is a state-of-the-art plant constructed in 2002.

The refrigeration system is a standard closed-loop design with two distinct refrigeration loops, the high stage/icemaker system and the low stage/freezer system.  The system has five screw compressors, four evaporative condensers, ten P-34A-XL-LOF Vogt ice machines, two recirculators, a thermosyphon vessel, a controlled pressure receiver vessel, nine evaporators and a water chiller.  A Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) monitors the system and controls the system operation.  In addition to the PLC, each of the compressors has numerous protective controls (motor overload, high discharge temperature, high discharge pressure, low suction pressure, and low oil pressure), which will shut down the compressor if operating limits are exceeded.  Pressure relief valves are installed on all pertinent equipment and are piped to discharge to a water-filled diffusion tank in the event of a release. 

The facility has multiple safeguards pertinent to the anhydrous ammonia process.  These include emergency ventilation systems, controls that shut down the compressors if operating limits are exceeded, and the capability of shutting down the entire system remotely if required.  An ammonia detection and alarm system is installed to notify employees in the event of an ammonia leak.  

Anhydrous ammonia, when properly used, has proven to be a safe and reliable refrigerant.  The sharp odor of ammonia provides its own warning agent.  Practically all accidents involving anhydrous ammonia can be avoided through the facility's program of proper employee training; knowledge of the equipment and procedures; and the development, maintenance, and implementa

tion of effective operating and maintenance procedures for all ammonia equipment.

Reddy Ice-Dallas has also developed an emergency action plan ("EAP") that includes: procedures for notification of emergency authorities/agencies and the public; evacuation of personnel; use of emergency alarms and equipment; employee training in evacuation procedures; and periodic review and updating of the written plan.

RISK MANAGEMENT PREVENTION PROGRAM 3
Based on the Reddy Ice-Dallas facility's ammonia inventory, location, and requirement to meet OSHA PSM regulations, it has been determined the facility is subject to Accident Prevention Program 3 requirements.  This accident prevention program is a way to make safe operations and accident prevention systematic throughout the facility.  Reddy Ice Corporate Management and Reddy Ice-Dallas management are committed to operating a safe and compliant facility for the protection of its employees, the public, and the environment.  A combined Process Safety Management/Risk Management ("PSM/RMP") Program has been developed to meet the accidental release prevention requirements of EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68) and OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) regulations.  The combined PSM/RMP Program contains fourteen elements, establishing requirements for:  employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity, hot work permits, contractors, incident investigation, compliance audits, emergency planning and response, and trade secrets.  These elements are tied together by a management system to ensure development, implementation, and integration of the Program requirements.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM
A management system has been developed to oversee the implementation of the PSM/RMP Program elements.  The Plant Manager has been identified as the "PSM/RMP Program Coordinator," with over

all responsibility for developing, implementing, and integrating the program requirements.  Under the PSM/RMP Program, various responsibilities have been assigned to other individuals.  The MP&V Supervisor is responsible for portions of the program closely tied to the refrigeration equipment and operation.  A safety committee with rotating membership meets each month to present a safety meeting and address any safety issues brought up by employees during the month.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
As required by the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations, the Reddy Ice-Dallas facility has conducted a hazard assessment including offsite consequence analyses (OCA) for potential accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  The OCAs describe the potential offsite exposure to surrounding areas from an accidental release.  A worst-case release scenario and alternative release scenarios were calculated using the EPA RMP*Comp modeling program, and the potentially affected offsite population and facilities were identified. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Reddy Ice-Dallas facility has not had any releases that would require reporting as part of a five-year accident history.

EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE
The Reddy Ice-Dallas facility operates under an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that includes procedures for:  notifying the public and local emergency responders; emergency evacuation procedures; use of emergency alarms and equipment; employee training in evacuation procedures; first aid for ammonia exposure; and periodic review and updating of the EAP. The plan is reviewed regularly for verification of data, and revised and updated as necessary to reflect changes in facility operations and personnel.

In addition, the facility has coordinated emergency response activities with the Dallas County LEPC and the Dallas Fire Department, and has appropriate mechanisms in place to notify emergency responders if needed.  The ammonia inventory is verified and reported annually to the st

ate and local authorities, and the plant is incorporated into the community emergency response plan developed under 42USC.

PLANNED CHANGES
The Reddy Ice-Dallas facility is a recently constructed state-of-the-art ice production facility.  No significant changes are planned to the facility or operations.  Reddy Ice facilities operate an ongoing program of preventive and predictive maintenance to identify and implement changes that may result in improved safety and operations.
